makers.displaydate: 1931–2022; born Providence, RI; died Florida; active Orbisonia, PA and New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Lee Bontecou, 1931–2022; born Providence, RI; died Florida; active Orbisonia, PA and New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: Dark voids and hypnotic, illusionistic recesses are the hallmarks of Lee Bontecou’s oeuvre. In this untitled drawing, an oculus with a shadowy center is bisected by a series of three smaller voids. At once corporeal and mechanical, the circular work suggests spinning propellers and speeding planes. Bontecou came of age during the Second World War, and her practice responds to the anxiety and excitement, common in the 1950s, about nuclear proliferation and space exploration. While on a Fulbright scholarship in Rome between 1956 and 1958, Bontecou started to employ state-of-the-art industrial machinery for the most elemental of artistic pursuits: drawing. Such is the case with Untitled, comprised of graphite and the soot from a portable acetylene torch, which the artist released onto the canvas by reducing the torch’s oxygen flow. The layers of soot were then manipulated through erasure and scraping. What results is an unusual collaboration between artist and machine.

Dark voids and hypnotic, illusionistic recesses are the hallmarks of Bontecou’s oeuvre. In this untitled drawing on a circular canvas, an oculus with a shadowy center is bisected by a series of three smaller voids. Like much of Bontecou’s early work, it was produced with graphite as well as with an acetylene torch that “drew” with soot, which she then manipulated through erasure and scraping, resulting in a work that is at once industrial and handmade. The artist Donald Judd championed Bontecou’s imagery, celebrating its abstract elusiveness. He insisted that her artwork was “an assertion of herself, what she feels and knows.” At once corporeal and mechanical, these forms suggest spinning propellers, speeding planes, and the cosmos.
[Leo Castelli Gallery, New York, NY]; sold to the Princeton University Art Museum, 1964.
